bug.author: treuille
bug.summary: st.number_input doesn't accept reasonable int arguments
bug.description:
<denchmark-h:h1>Summary</denchmark-h>
Using st.number_input in a very reasonable way: x = st.number_input("x", 0, 10) causes an exception to be thrown <denchmark-code>StreamlitAPIException: All arguments must be of the same type. value has float type. min_value has int type. max_value has int type.
Traceback: x = st.number_input("x", 0, 10) </denchmark-code>
<denchmark-h:h2>Expected behavior:</denchmark-h>
This should "just work," in the sense that it should create a number input that accepts ints between 0 and 10, with an initial default value of 0. <denchmark-h:h2>Actual behavior:</denchmark-h>
You get the exception above. You can "trick" Streamlit into providing the right behavior by forcing the value parameter to have type int as follows: x = st.number_input("x", 0, 10, 0) But I think this should just work without that extra parameter. <denchmark-h:h2>Is this a regression?</denchmark-h>
?? <denchmark-h:h1>Debug info</denchmark-h>
Streamlit version: Streamlit, version 0.73.0 Python version: Python 3.8.5 Python environment: pipenv, version 2020.11.4 OS version: Ubuntu 20.04.1 LTS

comments.comment: Thanks <denchmark-link:https://github.com/treuille>@treuille</denchmark-link> , that looks like behaviour we can definitely improve.
